Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: The client’s case involves important disputes that require careful representation
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, my phone buzzing in my pocket with reminders about the court hearing in two hours. My little brother, helmet askew, eyed the steep, cracked ramp with a mix of excitement and nerves. “Watch this, I’ve got it this time,” he called, gripping his skateboard. As his sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, to make sure he didn’t get hurt. But my mind kept drifting to the thick file in my bag—my client’s case was complicated, and I needed every spare minute to review the evidence and prepare my arguments. If I stayed to supervise my brother, I’d lose precious time for my client, who was counting on me to represent them well. If I left, I’d be abandoning my brother at a risky moment. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. My heart pounded as I watched my brother set his board down, torn between the ramp and the courtroom, between family and duty.
